title: Celebrity Gardens: Dries Van Noten’s Belgian Home and Gardens
text:
Photographed by François Halard, these pictures originally appeared in “Garden of Eden,” by Hamish Bowles , in the March 2014 issue of Vogue.
Though fashion is notoriously fickle, Dries Van Noten is a designer with deeply settled roots whose work communicates a quiet confidence. Several times a year, Van Noten takes his collections to Paris. The French capital is a world away from the gray industriousness of Antwerp, company headquarters, and even farther from Ringenhof, the vast estate he shares with partner Patrick Vangheluwe in Lier. Though the town is medieval, Van Noten’s Neoclassical house was built in the 1840s and remodeled after being shelled during the First World War. With the help of Gert Voorjans , an interior designer who also works on store design for the brand, Van Noten and Vangheluwe have created a beautiful haven, one that expresses the designer’s love of textiles, as well as flowers. Landscape architect Erik Dhont designed the 55-acre park and gardens that have Van Noten, a meticulous and hands-on gardener, happily in their thrall, and unceasingly inspired.
